results.title: Cincinnati automatic cycle press brake
results.brief_description: Shows the machine in action, from forming ‘flat’ sheets of metal on high speed or bending metal perfectly on slow speed. The machine has been revolutionary for workers helping them get the job done faster.

results.title: Cigarette smoking
results.brief_description:
This film shows the increase in cigarette smoking in the United States since World War I and how this increase has led to a large jump in the incidence of lung cancer. It also shows other diseases directly attributed to cigarette smoking.
Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Churchill: the finest hours
results.creator_credit: Peter Baylis, Jack Le Vien and Le Vien Films
results.brief_description: This lengthy biography of Winston Churchill is based on his own memoirs and narrated by Orson Welles. His early family life at Blenheim Palace, Harrow school and Sandhurst Military College is discussed, together with his military service in India and Cuba, and the occasions where he retreated from public life to devote time to his painting and writing. However, the primary focus of the program is on the contribution he made as Prime Minister of Britain during World War 2, rallying the people with his oratory and using his energies and determination to repel Hitler’s advances across Europe towards Britain. The program presents a good summary of the more important European military campaigns, with maps, and outlines the role played by Britain and its allies under Churchill’s leadership. It uses a large range of archival footage from various campaigns and cities across Europe and North Africa, interspersed with extracts of Churchill delivering key addresses.

results.title: Churchill: champion of freedom
results.creator_credit: George Grafton Green and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: Follows the life of Churchill from his entry into politics, his part in World War I, his early prediction of World War II and his defiant unconquerable leadership of his government, Britain, and the free world against Hitler. He saw his statue unveiled in Guild Hall, became Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports; and was revered by all on his 80th birthday - he became a legend in his lifetime. Includes 1911 film footage of Churchill as Home Secretary at the siege of Sydney Street, London’s East End. Commentary by Wynford Vaughan-Thomas.

results.title: Christmas under fire
results.creator_credit: Crown Film Unit and GPO Film Unit
results.brief_description: An emotional commentary, written and spoken by Quentin Reynolds, one of WWII’s best reporters, on the eve of his departure back to America, with a film report on how British people were celebrating their first Christmas under blitz conditions in 1940. Shows them in shelters, on watch in fields, in the city and at their posts proving to the world that the people of Britain are equal to their testing, unbeaten, unconquered and unafraid. Carols sung by the choir of Kings College Chapel, Cambridge.

results.title: Christmas Island
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson and Christmas Island Phosphate Commission
results.brief_description: Christmas Island, in the Indian Ocean, provides a large part of the phosphate rock requirements used in Australia and New Zealand. The mining of this phosphate is the only industry on the island. This film covers all aspects of the mining operations, and also shows the social and domestic life of the people engaged in the industry.

results.title: Christmas in Germany: a story of giving
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: This film is a dramatisation of a little girl’s perceptions of Christmas in a German town, highlighting the charming traditional Christmas customs and delicate decorations and crafts of Germany. This film is suitable for lower secondary school levels. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.
